Guido Rodriguez isn’t the only Real Betis player Arsenal are following, as they also have an interest in Emerson Royal, according to reports.

Mundo Deportivo write that as well as Rodriguez, Emerson Royal is another player Arsenal scouts are closely monitoring for a possible transfer in the upcoming window.

Emerson’s situation is a little complicated, as Real Betis and Barcelona jointly paid €6m to Atletico Mineiro for part-ownership of the player’s economic rights in 2019.

Technically, he joined Barcelona and is currently on loan with Betis, but if Barca want to bring him back this summer, they have to pay Betis their €6m, plus an extra €3m.

If Betis and Barcelona decide to sell to Arsenal instead, they’d both receive 50% of the income. So presumably they wouldn’t consider a sale for any less than €12m at the very least.

Emerson has made 62 appearances at right-back in the last two seasons, scoring five goals and assisting 10. It’s not entirely clear what Barcelona want to do, and it’s largely up to them at this point.

The Catalan club have Sergiño Dest starting regularly for them at the moment, so they may consider Emerson surplus to requirements. But we’ll probably need to wait until the summer to find out.

Arsenal loan defender Harry Clarke picks up minor injury

When they announced their team news for the match against Exeter City on Tuesday, Oldham Athletic wrote that Harry Clarke wouldn’t be involved due to injury. They didn’t give any specific details, only confirming he’d “picked up a knock”.

It’s been a frustrating month for Clarke, as this is his second injury absence since March began. He missed four games in a row from March 6th to March 16th, before returning with a start on March 20th, but now he’s back on the sidelines again.

Clarke also missed out on the squad for a game in February due to the limit on the number of loanees allowed per game, but funnily enough, the centre-back returned to the team after they conceded four goals in his absence.

In general, the loan has been a positive experience for Clarke. He’s made 26 appearances (27 if you include the abandoned fixture against Forest Green Rovers), with the vast majority of them being starts.

Despite the recent hiccups, this season still looks like being a worthwhile one for Clarke overall. If he can return from this latest knock and end Oldham’s League Two season on a high, he’ll hope to move up the English football pyramid next season.
